com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.process
Class ProcessOutputStreamSettings

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.kevinarpe.papaya.process.ProcessOutputStreamSettings
Direct Known Subclasses:
ProcessOutputStreamSettingsAfterStart
@FullyTested
public class ProcessOutputStreamSettings
extends Object

This simple class holds the settings for child process output streams (either STDOUT or STDERR) before the child process starts. The parent class, AbstractProcessSettings, has two instances: one each for STDOUT and STDERR.

This class may not be instantiated directly. Normally, only class AbstractProcessSettings creates instances.

Author:
Kevin Connor ARPE (kevinarpe@gmail.com)

Method Detail

charset

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings charset(Charset cs)
Sets the Charset used to convert bytes read from STDOUT or STDERR to String. The default value is Charset.defaultCharset(), and works correctly in the vast majority of use cases.

This feature is only relevant if charCallback(Appendable) is set to a non-null value.

Returns:
reference to this
Throws:
NullPointerException - if cs is null
See Also:
Charset.defaultCharset(), _charset

charset

public Charset charset()
Retrieves the Charset used to convert bytes read from STDOUT or STDERR to String. The initial value is Charset.defaultCharset().

This feature is only relevant if charCallback(Appendable) is set to a non-null value.

See Also:
Charset.defaultCharset(), charset(Charset)

splitRegex

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings splitRegex(Pattern optRegex)
Sets the optional Pattern used to split incoming characters. The initial value is StringUtils.NEW_LINE_REGEX.

If this feature is enabled and a character-based callback is set, as bytes are read from the child process stream handle, they are converted to String using Charset from charset(). Then, the resulting String is then split using this regular expression using Splitter. Important note: The text matched by the regular expression is discarded! Remaining characters are saved between stream reads until the regular expression matches. When the child process terminates, all remaining characters are written to the character-based callback.

If the description above confuses, follow this example:

  • Pattern is "\n" (UNIX newline)
  • Remaining text is ""
  • Read #1: "abc\ndef"
    • Prepend remaining text (""): "abc\ndef"
    • Split to: "abc" and "def"
    • Write "abc" to char callback
    • Remaining text is "def"
  • Read #2: "\nghi\n"
    • Prepend remaining text ("def"): "def\nghi\n"
    • Split to: "def", "ghi", and ""
    • Write "def" to char callback
    • Then, write "ghi" to char callback
    • Remaining text is ""
  • Read #3: "jkl"
    • Prepend remaining text (""): "jkl"
    • Split to: "jkl"
    • Write nothing to char callback
    • Remaining text is "jkl"
  • Read #4: "mno"
    • Prepend remaining text ("jkl"): "jklmno"
    • Split to: "jklmno"
    • Write nothing to char callback
    • Remaining text is "jklmno"
  • Child process terminates
  • Write "jklmno" to char callback
This feature is only relevant if charCallback(Appendable) is set to a non-null value.

Parameters:
optRegex -
  • optional regular expression to split incoming characters
  • May be null
  • Must not match the empty string
Returns:
reference to this
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if optRegex is non-null and matches the empty string
See Also:
splitRegex(), StringUtils.NEW_LINE_REGEX, charset(Charset), charCallback(Appendable)

Retrieves the optional Pattern used to split incoming characters. The initial value is StringUtils.NEW_LINE_REGEX.

This feature is only relevant if charCallback(Appendable) is set to a non-null value.

Returns:
(optional) regular expression used to split incoming characters. May be null
See Also:

charCallback

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings charCallback(Appendable optCallback)
Sets the optional character-based callback for STDOUT or STDERR. As bytes are received from STDOUT or STDERR, they are converted to String using Charset from charset(), then appended to this callback. The initial character-based callback is null.

If incoming data needs to be processed in byte-based form, use byteCallback(ByteAppendable). The callbacks for character- and byte-based data are mutually exclusive. Neither, one, or both may be employed.

It is not a requirement to set a callback to receive incoming data from STDOUT or STDERR. Alternatively, there is a setting to accumulate all incoming data from STDOUT or STDERR via isDataAccumulated(boolean). This feature is also independent of callbacks to process incoming data.

A separate thread always is used by Process2 to read STDOUT or STDERR. Thus, incoming data is appended to the callback from a different thread than that used to start the process. This may be important for specialised implementations of Appendable. As a special case, this method does not accept StringBuilder, as it is not thread-safe. Use StringBuffer instead.

If ProcessBuilder2.redirectErrorStream() is enabled, all data from STDERR is redirected to STDOUT. This may help to simplify processing logic, at the expense of distinguishing from STDOUT and STDERR data.

The Appendable interface is somewhat cumbersome with three methods. There is a simplified version to reduce boilerplate code: AbstractSimplifiedAppendable. Also, there is a full sample implementation: AppendablePrintLineWithPrefix.

If the character-based callback has state, such as StringBuffer, and multiple child processes are started from a single ProcessBuilder2, a factory should instead be set via charCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0).

All calls to this method, which do not throw exceptions, clear previous settings to charCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0).

To capture child process output and write to a file, consider using a BufferedWriter that wraps a OutputStreamWriter. This allows for full control over Charset, with buffering for more efficient I/O.

Parameters:
optCallback -
  • (optional) Appendable reference to receive incoming data from STDOUT.
  • Must not be an instance of StringBuilder, which is not thread-safe. Instead use StringBuffer.
  • May be null.
Returns:
reference to this
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if optCallback is an instance of StringBuilder
See Also:
charset(Charset), splitRegex(Pattern), charCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0), charCallback(), byteCallback(ByteAppendable), isDataAccumulated(boolean), Process2.redirectErrorStream()

If the character-based callback has state, such as StringBuffer, and multiple child processes are started from a single ProcessBuilder2, a factory should instead be used.

byteCallback

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings byteCallback(ByteAppendable optCallback)
Sets the optional byte-based callback for STDOUT or STDERR. As bytes are received from STDOUT or STDERR, they are appended to this callback.

If incoming data needs to be processed in character-based form, use charCallback(Appendable). The callbacks for character- and byte-based data are mutually exclusive. Neither, one, or both may be employed.

It is not a requirement to set a callback to receive incoming data from STDOUT or STDERR. Alternatively, there is a setting to accumulate all incoming data via isDataAccumulated(boolean). This feature is also independent of callbacks to process incoming data. This means it is possible to process data from both STDOUT and STDERR simultaneously (and separately) in both character- and byte-based form. If the accumulator feature is enabled, after the process has started, call one of these methods to access the accumulated data:

  • STDOUT:
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsByteArr()
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsString()
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsString(Charset)
  • STDERR:
    • Process2.stderrDataAsByteArr()
    • Process2.stderrDataAsString()
    • Process2.stderrDataAsString(Charset)
A separate thread always is used by Process2 to read STDOUT or STDERR. Thus, incoming data is appended to the callback from a different thread than that used to start the process. This may be important for specialised implementations of Appendable.

If isDataAccumulated() is enabled, all data from STDERR is redirected to STDOUT or STDERR. This may help to simplify processing logic, at the expense of distinguishing from STDOUT and STDERR data.

If the byte-based callback has state and multiple child processes are started from a single ProcessBuilder2, a factory should instead be set via byteCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0).

All calls to this method, which do not throw exceptions, clear previous settings to byteCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0).

Parameters:
optCallback -
  • (optional) ByteAppendable reference to receive incoming data from STDOUT or STDERR.
  • May be null.
Returns:
reference to this
See Also:
byteCallback(), isDataAccumulated(boolean), Process2.redirectErrorStream()

byteCallback

Retrieves the byte-based callback for STDOUT. Default value is null.

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings byteCallbackFactory(FuncUtils.Func0<ByteAppendable> optCallbackFactory)
Sets the factory to create a new byte-based callback. The initial value is null.

If the byte-based callback has state and multiple child processes are started from a single ProcessBuilder2, a factory should instead be used.

All calls to this method clear previous settings to byteCallback(ByteAppendable).

Parameters:
optCallbackFactory - optional byte-based callback factory. May be null.
Returns:
reference to this
See Also:

Returns:
may be null
See Also:

isDataAccumulated

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings isDataAccumulated(boolean b)
Sets whether or not the child process manager should accumulate incoming data from this stream (either STDOUT or STDERR). The default setting is disabled (false). This feature may be controller from the builder (ProcessBuilder2) or the child process (Process2). After the child process has started, it is still possible to enable or disable this feature.

If this feature is enabled, it is crucial to also set maxAccumulatedDataByteCount(int). By default, an unlimited amount of data is accumulated. If a large number of processes are launched simultaneously and each outputs a large amount of data on STDOUT or STDERR, the parent Java Virtual Machine may easily exhaust available memory.

If this feature is enabled, call one of these methods to access the accumulated data while the child process is running or after it has terminated:

  • STDOUT:
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsByteArr()
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsString()
    • Process2.stdoutDataAsString(Charset)
  • STDERR:
    • Process2.stderrDataAsByteArr()
    • Process2.stderrDataAsString()
    • Process2.stderrDataAsString(Charset)

Parameters:
b - if true, all incoming data from STDOUT is accumulated
Returns:
reference to this
See Also:
isDataAccumulated(), maxAccumulatedDataByteCount(int), Process2.stdoutDataAsByteArr(), Process2.stdoutDataAsString(), Process2.stdoutDataAsString(Charset), Process2.stderrDataAsByteArr(), Process2.stderrDataAsString(), Process2.stderrDataAsString(Charset)

isDataAccumulated

public boolean isDataAccumulated()
Retrieves the setting for the data accumulation feature for this stream (either STDOUT or STDERR). The default value is false.

maxAccumulatedDataByteCount

public ProcessOutputStreamSettings maxAccumulatedDataByteCount(int max)
Sets the maximum number of bytes to accumulate from this stream (either STDOUT or STDERR). This feature is only relevant if isDataAccumulated() is enabled.

It is very important to configure this feature in parallel with isDataAccumulated(). It is easy for a errant process to produce gigabytes of data on STDOUT or STDERR and exhaust all available memory for the parent Java virtual machine.

Parameters:
max - any value except zero. Negative value implies this feature is disabled.
Returns:
reference to this
See Also:
maxAccumulatedDataByteCount(), isDataAccumulated()

maxAccumulatedDataByteCount

public int maxAccumulatedDataByteCount()
Retrieves the maximum number of bytes to accumulate from this stream (either STDOUT or STDERR). This feature is only relevant if isDataAccumulated() is enabled.

Returns:
if negative, this feature is disabled
See Also:
maxAccumulatedDataByteCount(int), isDataAccumulated()
